summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York yesterday entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in a civil action brought by a former employee of JV Industrial Co., Ltd., alleging that he was exposed to a high concentration of H2S gas and other dangerous chemicals while working in a MWV refinery.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in New Orleans, JVI and its insurers, Steadfast Insurance Company (Steadfast) and AIG Specialty Insurance Co. (ASIC), claimed that on or about April 27, 2008, Baltazar Ortiz of DeRidder, Louisiana, who was an additional insured under MWV's agreement, had been exposed to high concentrations of the gas and dangerous chemicals during the course of JVI's work at the refinery. The complaint alleges that MWV violated the antifraud provisions of Section 23(a) of the agreement and, with prejudice, the pre-judgment provision of Section 9 of the Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The court also found that the defendants violated Section 9(a)(3) and Rule 9b2-3 thereunder, and that the SEC is entitled to a judgment ordering a permanent injunction against the defendants, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New Orleans today announced criminal charges against MWV.  A hearing on the matter was scheduled for May 24, 2013, for which the SEC appreciates the assistance of the U.N. Office of Insurance Regulation (OIC).
